titleStmt.title: How to Help Clients Make Effective Decisions About Romantic Relationships: A Systematic Review

affiliation.orgName: School of Behavioural and Health Sciences
School of Behavioural and Health Sciences
School of Behavioural and Health Sciences

analytic.title: How to Help Clients Make Effective Decisions About Romantic Relationships: A Systematic Review

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: When contemplating whether to stay or leave romantic relationships, people use a range of interventions to assist decision-making. Our aim was to systematically review the effectiveness of these interventions. We searched four databases using titles and abstracts to find eligible studies. Those using any design, intervention and population that explored stay/leave decisions were included. We conducted full-text screening, data-extraction, and risk of bias assessments in duplicate using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool, and evidence was synthesised. Searches retrieved 13,013 unique studies, and after screening 104 full-texts, six met inclusion criteria. Online decision aids led to short-term reductions in decisional conflict for women experiencing domestic violence (DV) who were contemplating leaving their partners. Motivational interviewing revealed mixed findings. Finally, a coin flipping intervention was a weak, yet interesting and beneficial strategy to assist stay/leave decisions. Given the scarcity of literature, further research in this area is required to ensure that clinicians are using evidence-based tools with clients who are contemplating dissolution. Future research should focus on identifying and examining strategies that assist stay/leave decisions specifically, and whether interventions from other decision-making domains can apply to stay/leave decisions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Relationships are a critical source of wellbeing and meaning. The saying "happy wife, happy life," is more than just a humorous phrase. Happy relationships are critical to one's subjective well-being and overall life satisfaction. Research has demonstrated a strong association between the quality of romantic relationships and happiness across the life-span, suggesting that more enjoyable relationships result in increased happiness (Berry & Willingham 1997;Campbell et al. 2005;Demir, 2010;Hadden & Knees, 2018;Rhoades et al. 2011;and Verbakel, 2012).

Conversely, unhappy relationships result in higher cortisol levels (i.e. stress) compared to happy couples (Berry & Worthington, 2001). There is also evidence to suggest that happy relationships can improve lifespan, with people in happy marriages living longer (Verbakel, 2012). Being in any kind of relationship rather than being unpartnered is beneficial for happiness, with some research even indicating that divorced women rank lower on subjective well-being than widowed women (Verbakel, 2012). These findings highlight the unique role that romantic relationships have on overall happiness and health. Whilst unhappy relationships are detrimental to subjective well-being, leaving those relationships can cause even more distress during the following year (Clarke et al. 2008;Verbakel, 2012). This reveals how difficult it is for a client to predict whether they would be better off after leaving a relationship.

The partner we choose can influence everything from our living and working arrangements, to our friends, and our health behaviours (Hausenblas et al. 1997;Manning et al. 2009). A decision to leave a relationship is significantly intertwined with these complex factors. Morrison and Roese (2011), found that unsuccessful romantic decisions are one of the most DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 4 commonly mentioned life regrets. How can someone predict whether their wellbeing would be higher by leaving their partner if there are so many downstream effects? Given that our life trajectory is heavily influenced by romantic relationships, it is important that clinicians can provide evidence-based strategies to help people contemplating dissolution.

div.head: Stay/Leave Relationship Decisions are Critical Hinges in a Person's Life
div.p: This thesis aimed to identify evidence-based strategies for making these decisions effectively. Effective decision-making is defined as a "systematic problem-solving process which involves identifying and choosing between alternatives based on one's values, beliefs, and preferences" (Janis & Mann, 1977;Spencer et al. 2012). Choosing to leave a partner is one of the hardest decisions people face. In a survey of 6,000 people, participants were presented with a list of life-changing decision-making questions or had the option to create their own question. Of those decisions, decisions about intimate relationships-such as whether to leave a partner, propose, or have children-were found to be three of the top 8 important decisions that people make, with stay/leave decisions being the most prominent (Levitt, 2016).

As a result, there is a considerable amount of relationship advice out there, however it can be difficult to evaluate the effectiveness of the advice. Relationship decisions are a difficult context for research (Gómez-López, et al. 2019). A client might feel the impact of divorce for decades, demonstrating the difficulty in evaluating long term outcomes. Similarly, it can be difficult to assess the counterfactual: what would have happened if the client had stayed in the relationship?

div.head: Research Describes Factors That Influence People's Stay/Leave Decisions
div.p: Qualitative research gives clinicians an organic sense of how people make stay/leave DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 5 decisions when left to their own devices. To examine this decision-making process, Fackrell (2012) conducted interviews with 31 individuals contemplating divorce. Findings suggest that people make seven prominent considerations, namely: (1) emotional and physical impact on themself;
(2) children (if present); (3) friendship and positive memories with partner; 4religion; (5) commitment; (6) social impact and support of family/friends; and (7) finances.

Participants commented that the decision-making process can be a "chaotic and confusing one", yet a necessary process to endure before deciding. Willén and Montgomery (2006) also examined decision-making strategies through semi-structured interviews on 12 couples considering divorce. Findings showed that couples employed one or more of the following strategies: (1) cognitive strategies such as focusing on the good; de-emphasising or inflating negative events; fateful explanations for negative behaviour; mentally exploring alternative partners (2) interactional strategies including increasing investments in the relationship; blaming/criticising or provoking the partner; emotional distancing; and (3) preparatory strategies including exploring alternative partners;

exploring practical solutions/gathering information; and nurturing a separate self. Findings revealed the strategies helped the initiating partner to emotionally distance themselves, which helped them make a final stay or leave decision (Willén & Montgomery, 2006).

div.head: Intervention Research has the Capacity to Make Stronger Causal Claims
div.p: Qualitative studies provide valuable anecdotal evidence, however, intervention research is more robust when trying to determine causal relationships between strategies and decision outcomes. When people attempt to reflect and report on their cognitive processes (e.g., on the reasons why people make a decision) they do not do so accurately (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977; DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 6 Wilson, 2004). Instead, people generally describe why they decided something based on what is the most plausible cause of the given response (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977). This suggests that we rarely have insight into our reasons for doing things, and highlights that asking people "why" after the fact is subject to post-hoc rationalisations and cognitive biases.

div.head: Objectives
div.p: Whilst there is some research identifying interventions people use to make stay/leave decisions, there are no systematic reviews comparing these interventions. Conducting systematic reviews are crucial to constructing evidence-based decision aids, clinical practice guidelines, and undertaking decision analyses . Until a systematic review is conducted, the relative effectiveness of those strategies is hard for clinicians to determine.

This thesis aims to identify and review interventions that help people make stay/leave decisions within their romantic relationships. This thesis also aims to determine moderation effects influencing the relative effectiveness of the interventions. Ultimately, we want to know what strategies best help people decide so clinicians can use best practice when working with clients.

div.head: Protocol and Registration
div.p: The study was registered at PROSPERO, International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews website (protocol number CRD42020156983).

div.head: Eligibility Criteria
div.p: The systematic review was conducted in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analayses (PRISMA; Moher, Liberati, Tetzlaff, & Altman, DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 7 2009). The studies within this review were selected using the following criteria:
1. participants of any age in a romantic relationship, who are contemplating breaking up with their partner;
2. any form of intervention research that focused on decision-making (as defined above), measuring any outcome;

3. any comparison condition was considered, including pre-post interventions; 4. or logistical reasons, only articles published in English, or those with an English translation, were used; and 5. Published and unpublished studies were included to reduce publication bias.
Purely qualitative studies (e.g., "why did you leave your partner?") were excluded because post-hoc rationalisations of client decisions are prone to bias (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977).

Purely observational studies were also excluded (e.g., "what predicts divorce?") as observational data do not necessarily inform intervention design. Relationship counselling was also excluded, if the only goal of the counselling was to repair the relationship, rather than to decide whether or not the couple wants to break up.

div.head: Information Sources
div.p: Initial scoping searches were conducted via Google Scholar. Then, a search using titles and abstracts was conducted from the following four databases: PsycINFO, SCOPUS, MEDLINE, and Cinahl. These databases were chosen due to their comprehensive data and subject coverage, and their use in similar reviews (Bruijniks et al. 2019;Garratt et al. 2007;Lemmens et al. 2016;Stockton et al. 2019). Forward and backward searches were conducted for any additional eligible studies . Also, authors of the selected studies DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 8 were contacted to obtain further relevant studies, including unpublished works.

div.head: Search
div.p: Using the criteria above, the following search strategy was generated to identify relevant context, interventions, populations and exclusions, respectively (formatted for SCOPUS):

div.head: Decision Making
div.p: TITLE-ABS ( "decision-making" OR "decision making" OR "life decision*" OR "decision aid*" OR "important decision*" OR "debias*" OR "good decision*" OR "life-changing decision*" OR "life changing decision*" OR "decision theory" OR "decision support system" OR "interpersonal decision*" OR "personal decision*" OR "stay/leave decisions*" OR "stay leave decisions*" ) AND Interventions TITLE-ABS ( interven* OR therap* OR advice OR counsel* OR "mental model*" OR strateg* ) AND Relationships TITLE-ABS ( "romantic relationship*" OR marri* OR partner* OR wife OR husband OR boyfriend OR girlfriend OR "domestic violence" OR divorce* OR dissolution OR breakup* OR "break up*" OR romantic* OR intimate OR couple* OR spouse* ) AND NOT Exclusions SUBJAREA ( ceng OR chem OR comp OR eart OR ener OR engi OR envi OR mate OR math OR phys OR agri OR bioc OR immu OR neur OR phar )

div.head: Study Selection
div.p: Results of the search were imported into Covidence systematic review management program (Covidence, 2017), where duplicates were removed. Title and abstracts were screened independently and in duplicate by two reviewers. Full-text screening was also done independently and in duplicate. Any discrepancies among authors were adjudicated by a third reviewer.

div.head: Data Collection Process and Data Items
div.p: One author extracted the data from each study including: the age, sex, relationship type (e.g. married, de-facto, living separately, etc), relationship length, employment status, whether partners were cohabiting and the presence of children. The study design, study population, and details of intervention, comparison group and outcome measures were also extracted, as recommended in Higgins and Altman (2008). A second author audited the studies by extracting outcome data of each study blindly and in duplicate to ensure accuracy. To facilitate comparisons between studies, available data was used to calculate standardised mean differences (d) using the conversion formula provided by Lipsey and Wilson (2001).

div.head: Risk of Bias in Individual Studies
div.p: The Cochrane Risk of Bias assessment was used because it has greater validity, sensitivity, and specificity than quantitative measures of bias (Higgins & Altman, 2008). Two authors independently completed the risk of bias judgments for the selected studies. If required, disagreements were adjudicated by a third author. This information was used in the synthesis to weight the findings with a lower risk of bias (See Table 3).

div.head: Summary Measures
div.p: The primary outcome registered with PROSPERO was subjective well-being/life satisfaction, which we considered to be roughly equivalent for the purposes of synthesis.

div.head: Synthesis of Results
div.p: Quantitative syntheses via meta-analysis are only applicable when comparing studies using homogenous participants, interventions, comparison groups and outcome measures (Deeks, et al. 2011). Where two or more studies were comparable, I conducted a meta-analysis of standardised mean differences. To manage multiple effect sizes from the same study, I conducted a multilevel meta-analysis using the metasem package (Cheung, 2014) in R (R Core Team, 2020).

div.head: Study Selection
div.p: The full study selection process is detailed in the PRISMA flow chart (see Figure 1).

After duplicates were removed, 13,013 papers were screened by two authors at the title and abstract level, then 104 full-texts were reviewed. Of those, 48 studies were excluded as they did not use an intervention (e.g., Paluso, 2004), 22 were qualitative studies (e.g., Beckerman & Shepherd, 2002), nine studies explored couples who had already made the stay/leave decision (e.g., Hall & Fincham, 2006), six were book reviews (e.g., Bruce, 1994), four only investigated repairing the relationship (e.g., Alger, 1991), three studies did not allow access to the full-text (e.g., Applewhite, 1997), two were observational studies (e.g., Hill, 1999), two examined problem solving without a focus on deciding to stay or leave the relationship (e.g., Hegarty et al., 2013), one explored decision-making within the relationship (e.g., Boffo & Mannarini, 2015), one examined decision-making within non-romantic relationships (e.g., Ahmed, 2018) and one was a duplicate of an included study (e.g. . A total of six studies met the criteria to be included in the systematic review.

div.head: Study Characteristics
div.p: Total number of participants in the included studies was 3,071, with 2,154 of those in domestic violent relationships. Characteristics of the studies included in the systematic review are presented in Table 1. Two studies investigated the effectiveness of motivational interviewing on decision-making outcomes, three focused on online decision aids, and one explored whether flipping a coin helped people decide. One study reported the effects of these interventions on our primary outcome (life satisfaction/subjective wellbeing) and results from primary and secondary outcomes are listed in Table 2. [-0.186, .116], p =.75) at 12-month follow-up. In terms of stay/leave decisions, findings revealed that intervention participants were more likely to leave their abusive partner (63% vs 53%, p = .008).

Koziol and colleagues (2018) replicated the methods of Glass (2010) Participants' PTSD was also assessed via the PCL-C at 6-months and 12-months. Results showed no significant reductions between groups at 6-months (d = .09, 95% CI = [-.108, .279], p = .39) or 12-months (d = .11, 95% CI = [-.082, .305], p = .26).

div.head: Effects of Motivational Interviewing Intervention
div.p: Two studies investigated motivational interviewing (MI) as a means to help individuals experiencing DV decide whether or not to leave their partner (Rasmussen et al., 2008;Saftlas et al., 2014). Findings from Rasmussen and colleagues (2008) pilot study revealed that, compared to controls, intervention women were significantly more motivated for change (i.e. leave their partner) at posttest (d = .92, 95% CI [-.001, 1.84], p = .029), as measured through the University of Rhode Island Change Assessment (URICA). Ninety percent of participants fell into the high motivational category. However, interestingly, 77.8% of women in the control group decided to leave the relationship compared to 33.3% of intervention women.

Saftlas and colleagues (2014) randomised control trial also investigated the effectiveness of MI on 306 abused women for 6-months across a number of domains: readiness for change (measured using the "stage-of-readiness-to-change" derived from the transtheoretical model), depressive symptoms (assessed via the CESD-10, short version) and self-efficacy (via the Domestic Violence Coping and Self-Efficacy Scale). In terms of readiness to change, from pretest, intervention women were less likely to be in the precontemplation stage, and more likely to be in the action or maintenance stage at 6-months, however this difference was not significant compared to controls. Results showed no significant between-group reductions in depressive symptoms (d = -.27, 95% CI [-.541, .010], p = .07) or improvements in self-efficacy (d = 0.15, 95% CI [-.120, .429], p = .25) at 6-months.

div.head: Effects of Coin Flip Intervention
div.p: Levitt (2016) examined the effectiveness of flipping a coin to make stay/leave decisions among 917 participants who were contemplating dissolution. Participants were randomly assigned to either stay or leave their partners by tossing a coin. As 50% of participants are likely to follow the coin due to chance, it was hypothesised that if the coin flip has no impact on behaviour, then 50% of the actions taken should match the coin's assignment. Results found that 63% of participants' actions matched the recommendations of the coin flip. Therefore, an additional 13% of participants were found to follow the coin flip outcome. Those people were found to be significantly happier at 2 and 6-months post-intervention. Findings suggest that the impact of the coin flip accelerates changes that would have happened anyway; people contemplating dissolution may be: (1) overthinking decisions and (2) less happy with their decision if they stick to the status quo.

div.head: Pooled Effect Size Estimates
div.p: Few of the included studies described comparable participants, interventions, comparisons and outcomes. Nevertheless, we conducted exploratory meta-analyses for each outcome where two comparable studies ran similar interventions, as recommended by Ioannidis and colleagues (2008). No meta-analytic effect sizes were significant. Two reported effects on depression Koziol-McLain et al., 2018) but the pooled effect size was small, homogenous, and not significant (d = 0.04 [95% CI -0.03, 0.12]; I 2 = 0%). The same two studies reported on PTSD symptomology, but pooled effects were also not significant (d = 0.02 [95% CI -0.07, 0.11]; I 2 = 0%). Two studies reported effects on perceived decision conflict (Glass et al. 2010;Eden et al. 2015), but effects were not significant 0.58]; I 2 = 33%). Overall, these results should be considered exploratory due to only two studies contributing to each pooled effect; analyses may be under-powered.

div.head: Risk of Bias Within Studies
div.p: The Cochrane Risk of Bias for Randomised Controlled Trials was used to assess the risk of bias in the studies (see Table 3). Risk of bias in each study is assessed as low, high or unclear across the domains of bias. Four studies were rated as low, two unclear, and one high.
Participants were blinded in 50% of the studies with unclear or no blinding of personnel or

div.head: DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS
div.p: 18 outcome assessment present in any study. Within 83% of the studies, participants were randomly allocated into groups, and researchers were unaware of participant allocation in 66% of the studies. All preregistered outcomes were reported in 66% of the studies. Attrition rates were high risk of bias in one study.

div.head: Table 3
div.p: Risk of Bias

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this review, I sought to find interventions to help those contemplating relationship dissolution. All studies but one examined women in violent relationships. Online interventions demonstrated short-term effectiveness in helping women contemplating dissolution. Evidence suggests that women's decisional conflict significantly reduced compared to controls at post-intervention (Glass et al. 2010;Eden et al. 2015). Specifically, women felt more supported in their stay/leave decision and experienced less uncertainty in their choice. In contrast, and Koziol-Mclain et al. (2018) found decisional conflict did not significantly differ between groups at 3, 6, or 12-months follow-up. This suggests that, over time, people feel less conflicted in their decision regardless of whether they receive an intervention. Interestingly, findings from Glass and Colleagues (2017) indicate that intervention women were significantly more likely to leave their partner compared to controls, indicating that women may only need initial assistance reducing decisional conflict to make a change. No significant group differences for depressive symptoms were present in either study Koziol-Mclain et al. 2018). This indicates that online interventions are not more effective at alleviating depression than regular treatment services. As discussed earlier, both being in a bad relationship and leaving a partner reduce wellbeing, at least in the short term, so perhaps even 12-months follow-up is not long enough to see the emotional benefits of leaving an abusive relationship. Mixed results were found for reducing PTSD symptoms. Koziol-Mclain and colleagues (2018) study showed a significant reduction over a 12-month period whereas Glass and colleagues (2017) found no significant group differences. Robust studies with larger sample sizes are required to determine whether online interventions are effective in reducing PTSD symptomology.
Mixed findings for the effects of MI on helping women experiencing DV decide whether or not to leave their partner, or whether these decisions lead to favourable outcomes were found.

Rasmussen and colleagues (2008) study indicate that whilst MI-enhanced women were significantly more motivated to leave their abusive relationship, a lower percentage of women engaged left their partner. However, due to the small sample size (n = 20), differentials in the number of women who left the relationship translates into higher percentage differences, which may reflect a significant difference. Further, this study did not report if women who decided to DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 20 stay or leave their partner was a favourable decision outcome. This makes it difficult to determine whether the intervention improved women's wellbeing post-choice, and this finding should be interpreted with caution.

Conversely, Saftlas and colleagues (2014) study showed that MI-enhanced women were not significantly more motivated to make a stay/leave decision compared to controls. There were also no significant group differences found for reducing depressive symptoms or increasing self-efficacy. This suggests that MI did not meaningfully improve women's wellbeing or their confidence in their ability to decide whether or not to leave their abusive partner.

Only one intervention was found for nonviolent relationships: flipping a coin. This was found to be beneficial helping people contemplating dissolution, where people reported feeling happier at 2-months and 6-months post-intervention compared to pre-test. However, these results should be interpreted with caution due to the unorthodox reporting and the inability to judge bias (see Table 3). This recommendation is clinically controversial, because it's unlikely to be something that a therapist could recommend. As a result, we conducted a rapid overview of reviews (Haby et al., 2016;Pandor et al., 2019) of decision-making interventions from other fields to investigate strategies for other life-changing decisions (see [OSF link] for methods).
Systematic reviews on decision-making across areas such as medical treatment, resuscitation, and end-of-life decisions were found.

div.head: Treatment Decisions
div.p: Like relationship decisions, treatment decisions are consequential decisions that impact Van de Velde and colleagues (2018) analysed 3 studies to examine which factors make computerised clinical decision support strategies (CDS) more effective across five outcomes:

adherence to recommended practice, patient outcome measures, economic measures, patient satisfaction, and decision quality. Results also showed that CDS can potentially better inform decisions, and it can help with the management of information overload. However, across the three studies, there were no meaningful differences in decision satisfaction compared to patients who did not receive CDS. These three reviews suggest a number of interventions that therapists could adopt from treatment decisions. Specifically, they could clarify client values, help outline options, provide information about the likely outcomes from those options, and describe benefits and risks.

div.head: Resuscitation Decisions
div.p: Similar to relationship decisions, resuscitation decisions elicit strong emotional reactions from those involved. A systematic review by Field, et al. (2014) reducing misunderstandings, and may be a beneficial strategy for those making stay/leave decisions. Alternatively, they may provide an opportunity to pre-commit to a plan of action in response to a contingency (e.g., "if I end up in hospital again at the hands of my partner, I want to find temporary shelter elsewhere"). Similarly, a systematic review using 22 studies by Phillips et al. (2019) aimed to identify patients' decision-making needs and assess the extent to which decision aids addressed these needs. To assess the effectiveness of current decision aids, the International Patient Decision Aid Standards (IPDAS) was used. These standards aim to enhance the quality and effectiveness of decision aids by establishing an evidence-informed framework with a set of criteria for improving their content, development, implementation, and evaluation (see Appendix A).

div.head: End-of-Life Decisions
div.p: Results revealed that current decision aids (e.g., structured advanced care planning tools)
for those facing EOL decisions are insufficient at addressing the needs of this population.

Examples from the framework include questions such as: (1) does the decision aid provide enough information for the patient to make an informed decision? (2) does the decision aid present information in an unbiased way? And (3) does the decision aid include methods for clarifying and expressing the patient's values?

These findings suggest that a tool such as the IPDAS may be beneficial to adapt and incorporate in other areas of decision-making such as in stay/leave decisions. For example, the values-based section of the IPDAS could be adapted to help clients understand their values whilst contemplating dissolution. This would allow clinicians to more safely offer strategies to their clients by assessing whether the interventions they propose are meeting evidence-based requirements. Future research should be assessing whether these interventions help those contemplating dissolution in DV and/or non-violent relationships.

div.head: Limitations of Included Studies
div.p: Limitations of included studies reflect inconsistent adherence to Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials guidelines (CONSORT;Schultz et al., 2010). Specifically, only 50% of the studies reported blinding. This may have led to a performance bias or detection bias where improvements in decision-making are not causaly explained by the interventions. Further, in some studies, the small sample size and narrow study characteristics (i.e., almost all participants were women from DV populations) means the results are not generalisable to the wider population. Only three of the studies were randomised control trials. We kept the study design eligibility criteria broad to ensure that we captured intervention research of any design. However, due to inherent bias within non-randomised control trials, findings from those should be interpreted with caution, specifically since the randomised trials often showed significant reductions in decision conflict even in the control group. Future research should develop robust studies to investigate interventions where findings can be generalised.

div.head: Limitations of this Review
div.p: The number of eligible studies was very limited. It appears that there is a scarcity of literature available in this area, revealing the need for further research to investigate interventions that would assist stay/leave decisions. Although an effort was made to capture all eligible studies, some key terms such as 'Relationship' had low specificity due to other uses of the word (e.g., 'relationship' between variables). However, we conducted a comprehensive search (13,013 studies screened), contacted authors, and used forward and backward searching, so are likely to have collected most studies on this topic. As a result of our limited findings, I needed to make deviations from my registered protocol by not using the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation criteria (GRADE criteria). This was due to not finding enough studies for robust judgements to be undertaken. Finally, although we planned to explore moderators as a source of heterogeneity, there were not enough studies for adequately powered DECISIONS IN RELATIONSHIPS 25 moderation analyses.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Deciding whether or not to leave a partner is a painful and influential turning point in all of our lives. However, at this stage, the psychological literature has not yet provided good guidance regarding the best kinds of interventions for navigating those decisions. Given the scarcity of research within this space, we cannot yet make confident conclusions in terms of which interventions are best to help clients contemplating dissolution. Results highlight the need for more robust research in this area, particularly within non-violent relationships. Still, this thesis shows that there are some viable strategies to help reduce decisional conflict in women experiencing DV in the short term. This thesis also discusses a range of other strategies from other decision-making interventions that clinicians could use with other couples.

div.head: Funding
div.p: This systematic review was funded by the Australian Catholic University, Faculty of Health Sciences.

figure.figDesc: Study Characteristics URICA = University of Rhode Island Change Assessment Scale; Stage of Readiness = Stage-of-readiness-to-change tool (adapted from Burke et al. 2004) DCS = Decisional Conflict Scale; DCS-L = Decisional Conflict Scale -Low literacy version DVCE = Domestic Violence Coping and Self-Efficacy Scale CESD-R = Centre for Epidemiologic Studies Short Depression Scale -Revised; CESD-10 = Centre for Epidemiologic Studies Short Depression Scale PCL-C = Post-traumatic Checklist -Civilian version MI = Motivational Interviewing; TAU = Treatment as usual Effects of Online InterventionThree studies examined the effectiveness of online interventions to assist women contemplating dissolution within DV populations(Eden, et al. 2015; Glass, et al. 2010;Koziol-Mclain et al. 2018).Glass and Colleagues (2010) pilot study assessed 90 women using the low literacy version of the Decisional Conflict Scale (DCS) at pretest and posttest compared to controls. Findings indicate that intervention women experienced less total decisional conflict(d = .53, 95% CI [.108, .948], p = .01) at posttest compared to pre-test. Of the four subscales, women felt more supported in their decision to stay or leave their relationship at posttest(d = .54, 95% CI [.120, .961], p = .01). Scores on the other subscales of the DCS (feeling uncertain, uninformed, unclear about values) trended in the expected direction, but were not significant compared to the control group, suggesting that these women became less conflicted with or without tailored assistance.Eden and colleagues' (2015) randomised control trial also assessed decisional conflict using the DCS in 708 women. Similar findings indicate that intervention women had significantly lower total decisional conflict than the usual safety planning group at posttest (d = -.02, 95% CI[-.168, .126], p = .002). Specifically, women experienced a significant reduction in feelings of uncertainty (d = -.03, 95% CI[-.173, .120], p = .006), and in feeling unsupported (d = -.03, 95% CI[-.172, .121], p = .008) about their stay/leave decision. However, there were no significant group differences.Glass and colleagues (2017) followed up these participants (from Eden et al., 2015) after 12-months. Findings revealed that whilst decisional conflict reduced over time, there were no significant between-group differences at 6-months(d = .06, .207], p > .05) or 12-months (d = -0.08, 95% CI [-.226, 0.075], p > .05). Glass and Colleagues (2017) also investigated participants' depressive symptoms (measured using the Center of Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale-Revised; CESD-R), Post-Traumatic Stress (PTSD; via the Post-traumatic Checklist-civilian version; PCL-C) and whether they left their partner. Results found no meaningful group differences in depressive symptoms (d = .004, 95% CI [-.147, .155], p =.40) or PTSD symptoms (d = -.04, 95% CI

study using a different DV sample. Researchers assessed participants' depressive symptoms using the CESD-R and decisional conflict via the DCS at 3-months, 6-months, and 12-months. Reductions in depressive symptoms were not statistically significant between groups at 3-months (d = .09, 95% CI = [-.095, .292], p = .32), 6-months (d = .08, 95% CI =[-.110, .277], p = .40) or 12 months (d = .05, 95% CI =[-0.146, .241], p = .63). Similarly, there were no significant differences between groups for decisional conflict at 3-months (d = .07, 95% CI[-.120, .267], p = .46), 6-months(d = .05, .246], p = .6), or 12-months, (d =.03, 95% CI =[-.163, .224], p = .76).

multiple parties. Treatment decisions involve patients deciding among healthcare options, for example, "Which medication should I take?" Karagiannis and colleagues, (2019) evaluated patient decision aids (PtDAs) to assist people with Type 2 diabetes engage in decision-making about healthcare options. PtDAs aim to: define the decision; outline options; provide current evidence-based information on options, including the benefits and risks; and clarify values of the individual (McAlpine et al., 2018). Findings from 15 studies showed PtDAs helped patients be more actively involved in the decision-making process, reduced decisional conflict and improved patient knowledge compared to usual care. The decision outcomes were also tailored to the specific needs of the individual, resulting in greater choice satisfaction. Similar findings were found in McAlpine et al. (2018) study, who assessed PtDAs with cancer patients. Forty-six trials evaluated PtDAs for cancer care decisions including: screening decisions (27), treatments (12), genetic testing (4) and prevention (3). PtDAs also improved patient knowledge, accurate risk perception and value-choice agreement, decreased decisional conflict and indecisiveness compared to controls (usual care or different interventions).

examined 'do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation' (DNACPR) decision tools. Thirty-seven studies incorporated structured discussions about the treatment plan at the time of admission to hospital and reviews by specialist teams at the point of acute deterioration. The structured discussions aimed to clarify care goals to streamline communication and reduce harm to the client. Findings show that structured discussions (i.e., discussions confirming current healthcare wishes), provided greater clarity about goals of care, and aided communication between clinicians to reduce harm to the patient. Findings show that structured discussions can optimise the decision-making process by

Many decisions are made by patients in their last months of life, creating complex, decision-making needs for this group of people. A systematic review by Oczkowski, Chung, Hanvey, Mbuagbaw and You, (2016) investigated the effects of structured communication tools for end-of-life (EOL) decisions. The aim of structured communication tools was to improve care goals to assist EOL decision-making. Findings from 19 studies found that communication tools improved the documentation of goals-of-care discussions and ultimately decisions to withdraw life-sustaining treatments when compared to usual care.
